channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Justice Department scrutinized as its case against James Comey hits a new roadblock
item.description: The Justice Department's case against former FBI Director James Comey faced a new setback Wednesday, as questions mount over how prosecutors presented the indictment to the grand jury.
item.content:encoded: The Justice Department's case against former FBI Director James Comey faced a new setback Wednesday, as questions mount over how prosecutors presented the indictment to the grand jury.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Lucas

item.title: Ex-federal prosecutor talks about the future of the DOJ's case against James Comey
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with former federal prosecutor Elie Honig about efforts to dismiss the case against former FBI Director James Comey.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with former federal prosecutor Elie Honig about efforts to dismiss the case against former FBI Director James Comey.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: Eating just a handful of plastic can be fatal for marine animals, a study finds
item.description: Scientists have long known that plastic waste is bad for marine animals. A new study quantifies how little ingested plastic it takes to be a lethal dose.
item.content:encoded:
Scientists have long known that plastic waste is bad for marine animals. A new study quantifies how little ingested plastic it takes to be a lethal dose.

(Image credit: Michael O'Neill)
item.dc:creator: Nathan Rott

item.title: September jobs report arrives today, almost 7 weeks behind schedule
item.description: The Labor Department will report on hiring and unemployment. The report, which was delayed by a government shutdown, is somewhat stale but could offer clues about the strength or weakness of the job market.
item.content:encoded:
The Labor Department will report on hiring and unemployment. The report, which was delayed by a government shutdown, is somewhat stale but could offer clues about the strength or weakness of the job market.

(Image credit: Frederic J. Brown)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: The latest Epstein emails reveal the powerful people who sought his counsel
item.description: The latest emails from Jeffrey Epstein's estate show communications with a vast web of influential figures in politics, academia, business and more, even after he registered as a sex offender.
item.content:encoded:
The latest emails from Jeffrey Epstein's estate show communications with a vast web of influential figures in politics, academia, business and more, even after he registered as a sex offender.

(Image credit: Mehmet Eser)
item.dc:creator: Stephen Fowler

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: The Justice Department's case against James Comey hits a new hurdle, the latest Epstein emails reveal the powerful people who sought his counsel, tech giant Nvidia reports blockbuster earnings.
item.content:encoded: The Justice Department's case against James Comey hits a new hurdle, the latest Epstein emails reveal the powerful people who sought his counsel, tech giant Nvidia reports blockbuster earnings.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: Food banks, already strained, brace for prolonged demand
item.description: Now that SNAP food aid is flowing again, needy families are feeling relief. The same can't be said of many food banks and pantries. They're still feeling the strain because demand has yet to let up.
item.content:encoded: Now that SNAP food aid is flowing again, needy families are feeling relief. The same can't be said of many food banks and pantries. They're still feeling the strain because demand has yet to let up.
item.dc:creator: Tovia Smith

item.title: College costs have risen dramatically in the last 20 years. Here's why
item.description: It's no secret that going to college can be very expensive, with tuition costs rising faster than financial aid. But what's causing that price tag to rise so quickly?
item.content:encoded: It's no secret that going to college can be very expensive, with tuition costs rising faster than financial aid. But what's causing that price tag to rise so quickly?
item.dc:creator: Elissa Nadworny

item.title: Venezuelans share their concerns amid U.S. military buildup near the country
item.description: As Venezuela braces for potential U.S. military intervention, residents at the Colombia border tell NPR about their fears and hopes.
item.content:encoded: As Venezuela braces for potential U.S. military intervention, residents at the Colombia border tell NPR about their fears and hopes.
item.dc:creator: Carrie Kahn

item.title: Two senators want to hold big tech accountable for harm caused by their algorithms
item.description: Sens. Mark Kelly, D-Ariz.,and John Curtis, R-Utah, want to hold social media companies accountable for the negative impacts their algorithms have on people. They spoke to NPR about their bill.
item.content:encoded: Sens. Mark Kelly, D-Ariz.,and John Curtis, R-Utah, want to hold social media companies accountable for the negative impacts their algorithms have on people. They spoke to NPR about their bill.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep
